verses.text: A prophecy about Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum from Elkosh.
verses.comment: Nahum’s opening identifies this work as a prophetic oracle, like many Old Testament prophets (see Isa. 13:1). 'Vision' suggests divine revelation—the prophet speaks God's word, not his own.

verses.text: The LORD is a jealous and avenging God; the LORD takes vengeance and is filled with wrath. The LORD takes vengeance against his adversaries, and keeps wrath for his enemies.
verses.comment: God’s jealousy refers to his passionate commitment to his people, like Ex. 20:5 and Deut. 4:24. The depiction of God as avenger emphasizes his justice, timeless throughout salvation history.

verses.text: The LORD is slow to anger but great in power; and he will by no means leave the guilty unpunished. His way is in the whirlwind and the storm, and the clouds are the dust of his feet.
verses.comment: God’s patience is echoed in Ex. 34:6, yet his justice is unwavering (Ex. 34:7). ‘Clouds are the dust of his feet’ is poetic imagery about God’s sovereignty over creation, linking to other theophanies.

verses.text: He rebukes the sea and makes it dry; he dries up all the rivers. Bashan and Carmel wither, and the flowers of Lebanon fade.
verses.comment: God’s command over nature recalls the Exodus miracle (Ex. 14:21). Bashan, Carmel, and Lebanon, famed for their abundance, withering points to judgment affecting even the most prosperous.

verses.text: The mountains quake before him, and the hills melt away. The earth heaves at his presence—the world and all who dwell in it.
verses.comment: God’s overwhelming presence causes all creation to tremble, similar to Ps. 97:5 and Mic. 1:4. This points to his supreme authority, anticipating the eschatological shaking of all things (cf. Heb. 12:26-27).

verses.text: Who can stand before his indignation? Who can endure the fury of his anger? His wrath is poured out like fire, and the rocks are shattered before him.
verses.comment: This rhetorical question is found elsewhere (Ps. 76:7; Rev. 6:17) and underlines that no one can withstand God’s judgment, showing our total dependence on his mercy.

verses.text: The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; he knows those who take refuge in him.
verses.comment: In contrast to his wrath, God’s goodness and protection are offered to those who seek him. ‘Knows those’ has covenantal overtones, hinting at a familial relationship with his people, consistent with a visible community of faith.

verses.text: But with an overwhelming flood he will make a complete end of his foes, and he will pursue his enemies into darkness.
verses.comment: ‘Flood’ echoes Genesis and is a symbol of irresistible judgment. Darkness as a destination for God’s enemies recalls spiritual separation, often interpreted as the ultimate justice of God.

verses.text: What do you plot against the LORD? He will make a complete end; trouble will not rise up a second time.
verses.comment: Human schemes are futile against God’s purpose, related to Ps. 21:11. The finality of God’s judgment is emphasized: those judged are not judged again—hinting at a final, once-for-all act of divine justice.

verses.text: For they are tangled like thorns, and drunk like drunkards; they are consumed like stubble fully dry.
verses.comment: Thorns and stubble are consistent images of worthless and doomed opposition (see Isa. 10:17). ‘Drunkards’ indicates spiritual blindness from pleasure, disconnected from the discipline found in God’s true community.

verses.text: From you has come one who plots evil against the LORD, a wicked counselor.
verses.comment: Refers to Assyrian rulers, especially those who opposed Israel. False guidance stands in contrast to true spiritual leadership, which is recognized through apostolic succession and fidelity to revealed truth.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: 'Though they are at full strength and many, they will be cut down and pass away. Though I have afflicted you, I will afflict you no more.'
verses.comment: Assyria at its peak is no match for God’s power. Promise of relief for God’s people links to themes of restoration and divine compassion—hallmarks of the true, ongoing covenant community.

verses.text: Now I will break his yoke from you and tear your bonds apart.
verses.comment: Breaking the yoke is a common metaphor for liberation (Isa. 10:27). This anticipates God delivering his people in history—and spiritually, freedom offered through Christ and the sacraments.

verses.text: The LORD has given a command about you: 'Your name will no longer be spread; I will cut off the carved image and the cast idol from the house of your gods. I will prepare your grave, for you are vile.'
verses.comment: Divine judgment includes the destruction of idolatry. Removal of idols points to a call for pure worship, rooted in a visible, unified community of faith that guards truth and practice.

verses.text: Look! On the mountains the feet of one who brings good news, who proclaims peace! Celebrate your festivals, Judah, fulfill your vows! For the wicked will never again invade you; they are completely cut off.
verses.comment: This verse is quoted in Isaiah 52:7 and echoed in Rom. 10:15. 'Good news' and 'peace' point prophetically to the Gospel and Christ’s work. The mention of festivals and vows reveals continuity of worship and covenant faith, fulfilled in Christ who established public, sacramental worship.
